Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.
1. This is part of an elaborate chart that shows how funds were provided to the Nicaraguan rebels and others through a private network. Where was it found and why is that significant?
2. Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for the Democratic Presidential nomination may have increased his influence within his party instead of diminishing it. Why?

3. The arrest of four leading members of the main French underground terrorist organization, Direct Action, was timely, given the group's threat of imminent retaliation. Against whom was the threat directed?

4. The United States Supreme Court ruled that judges may order employers to use strict racial quotas to counter severe past discrimination against blacks. How did the Court's new ruling broaden its previous decisions on the subject?
5. The practice of feeding antibiotics to livestock to fend off disease may have a harmful side effect. What is it?
6. A speech in defense of ''democracy'' came from a most unlikely quarter. Who delivered it, and why?

7. At President Reagan's request, the Tower commission examined a variety of operations handled by the National Security Council staff in addition to the Iran-contra affair, including the United States invasion of Grenada and the terrorist attack on the cruise ship Achille Lauro. What conclusion did the panel draw from its review of these episodes?
8. Archeologists at the site of Fort Mose have found not only the ruins of a colonial fortification but also a nearly lost chapter of history. Explain.
9. Participants at a federally sponsored conference on the control of AIDS showed little support for mandatory or compulsory testing of any group for the disease. Why did they oppose the idea?

10. In separate legal challenges, two former White House aides, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Michael K. Deaver, have questioned the constitutionality of the Federal law that created the office of independent counsel, or special prosecutor. What is the basis for the challenges?

11. The Southern Methodist University football team was banned for the coming season and other penalties were imposed on it, but the team was spared the N.C.A.A.'s severest penalty. What is that? 12. The recent explosion of a giant star in a nearby galaxy, a very rare event, will be rarer still if can be linked to some spectrographic records of the stars taken a decade ago. Explain.
13. One of the nation's most elite law schools has adopted a program that will encourage alumni to go into public service or take other low-paying jobs. What school is it and what is the program?

14. In winning renomination as the Democratic choice for Mayor of Chicago, Harold Washington defeated his rival, Jane Byrne, by winning a larger proportion of white voters than she won among black voters. True or false?
15. This year's Grammy Awards, if they are truly a reflection of the music business, provided a somewhat surprising picture of the industry. What did most of the winners have in common?
16. A senior at Stanford University, Simone LeVant, is the only one of 15,000 college students to have said no. What is at issue?
